title: Statistical Analysis of the Effect on Growth Performance of Incorporating Fish Silage in the Diet of Pigs and Broilers in Galapagos
description:
In this analysis, I explored the effects of dietary supplementation with Fish Silage (FS) on the growth performance of pigs and broilers in the Galapagos Islands. For the broiler trials, I conducted statistical analyses using one-way ANOVA to assess the significance of differences in daily weight gain and feed conversion ratio (FCR) between groups fed with varying levels of FS. The results showed that the broilers fed with 12% FS had significantly better growth performance, with higher average daily weight gain and lower FCR, compared to the control group and the group fed with 6% FS. Additionally, Cohen's d was used to quantify effect sizes, and Tukey’s HSD test identified specific pairwise differences between treatments. 

The pig trial, although not statistically analyzed due to the small sample size, provided qualitative insights indicating that FS can be successfully used in pig diets without negatively impacting meat quality. Overall, the analysis demonstrated the practical feasibility and potential benefits of FS supplementation in the Galapagos agricultural sector.
contents:
Show code

#Read in data
general_pigs <- read_csv("general_pigs.csv") %>% 
  clean_names() %>% 
  na.omit(general_pigs) 

general <- read_csv("general.csv") %>% 
  clean_names()


1. Overview
This report provides an exploratory overview of the results obtained in pig and broiler trials designed to assess the effect of dietary supplementation of Fish Silage (FS) from Galapagos fisheries on local productions. These trials were implemented by Conservation International between the months of January and May 2022 in the canton of Santa Cruz, Galapagos.
Specifically, productive aspects were evaluated, comparing a control diet based on commercial feeds with diets containing different proportions of FS. Commercial feed and FS intakes, weight gains, and feed conversion ratios (FCR) were compared to estimate the relative effect of FS supplementation on pig and poultry production. In this way, the trials sought to characterize the practical feasibility and productive virtues of FS supplementation in the context of the Galapagos agricultural sector.
Note: for a detailed description of the experimental design see Annex 1. A general interpretation of the results and a cost-benefit analysis are provided in Annex 2 and 3.

 

2. Data and Methods
Productive information from the trials was collected by the technical team of Conservation International Ecuador during the period of January to May 2022. The data contains observations of 8 pigs and 96 broilers. For both the pig and broiler trials, an exploratory visualization of the measured traits was performed. This was extended for the broiler trial, testing the results for statistical significance using a significance level (\(\alpha\)) of 0.05. Differences between groups were described by Cohen’s d effect size. The statistical significance of these differences was explored by means of ANOVA. All analyzes were done in R version 4.2.0 using RStudio version 1.4.1743.

 

3. Results
A. Pigs
The trial in pigs was carried out between the months of January and March 2022 on a farm located in the Bellavista parish, Santa Cruz, Galapagos. Eight 45-day-old crossbred pigs were randomly distributed into two dietary treatments: a control diet (T1) and a diet with 8% (dry weight) of FS (T2). It was not possible to form replicates given the low number of animals under evaluation. The assessment period was 80 days, ending with animals of 125 days (about 65 kg body weight on average). The animals remained in facilities according to what was detailed in the experimental design (Annex 1) and the traits evaluated were: feed intake, FS intake, weight gain, and carcass yield. Additionally, a sensory evaluation of pork meat was carried out in the laboratory of the Escuela Superior Politécnica del Litoral (ESPOL).
No detailed statistical analyses were performed for this trial. The limited number of individuals under study and the intrinsic genetic variations between crossbred animals means that statistically significant results cannot be verified. The results of this trial are qualitative in nature, documenting the use of FS in Galapagos pig production.

bal_day_pigs <- bal_table_pigs %>% 
pivot_longer(
cols = "1":"79",
names_to = "day",
values_to = "mean_bal_consumption"
) %>% 
  mutate(day = as.numeric(day))


mean_bal_plot_pigs <- ggplot(data = bal_day_pigs, aes(x = day, y = mean_bal_consumption))+
  geom_line(aes(color = tratamiento))+
  scale_color_manual(values = c("cyan4","coral"))+
  labs(x = "Day",
       y = "Feed intake (g)",
       col="",
       title = "Feed intake - 80 day trial in pigs")+
  theme_minimal()

ggplotly(mean_bal_plot_pigs)%>% 
  layout(legend = list( x = 1, y = 0.5)) %>% 
  layout(legend=list(title=list(text='Treatment')))



Figure 1. Feed intake (g) for pigs of groups T1 and T2. Teal (T1) and coral (T2) lines indicate average feed intakes for each group. Data: trial carried out in Galapagos by Conservation International Ecuador during the months of January to March 2022.

pivot_longer(
cols = "1":"79",
names_to = "day",
values_to = "mean_fs_consumption"

  mutate(day = as.numeric(day))


mean_fs_plot_pigs <- ggplot(data = FS_day_pigs, aes(x = day, y = mean_fs_consumption))+
  geom_line(aes(color = tratamiento))+
  scale_color_manual(values = c("cyan4","coral"))+
  labs(x = "Day",
       y = "Fish Silage intake (g)",
       col="",
       title = "Fish Silage intake - 80 day trial in pigs")+
  theme_minimal()
ggplotly(mean_fs_plot_pigs)%>% 
  layout(legend = list( x = 1, y = 0.5)) %>% 
  layout(legend=list(title=list(text='Treatment')))



Figure 2. Fish Silage (FS) intake (g) for pigs of groups T1 and T2. Teal (T1) and coral (T2) lines indicate average FS intakes for each group. As can be seen, control treatment T1 did not consume FS. Data: trial carried out in Galapagos by Conservation International Ecuador during the months of January to March 2022.

As indicated above, the limited number and the genetic characteristics of the animals evaluated did not allow to verify statistically significant differences between the dietary treatments. Nevertheless, this trial showed that FS can be successfully used in Galapagos pig production as a feed supplement, achieving similar yields to those obtained with available commercial feeds.

 

b. Sensory Evaluation of the Meat
An organoleptic evaluation of the meat was carried out to assess the presence of fish flavor in the animals fed with FS. Samples from animals fed with and without FS were given to 31 untrained panelists. These samples were clustered into groups of three (two samples belonging to the same dietary treatment and a distinct one belonging to the other) asking the panelists to identify the distinct sample. The evaluation methodology assumes that if there were distinguishable differences between the dietary treatments, the panelists could identify the distinct sample with a frequency greater than 33% (probability of selecting the different sample simply by chance).

 

Table 2 Results of the sensory evaluation of pork meat from groups T1 and T2 carried out by the Escuela Superior Politécnica del Litoral (ESPOL).

The results deviate slightly from those expected due to chance if there were no distinguishable differences between the samples. However, according to Lawless and Heymann (2010), these differences are not enough to establish statistically significant differences. When asked, the panelists said that they had not noticed any unusual flavors in the samples tested.
B. Broilers
The trial in broilers was carried out between the months of April and May 2022 on a farm located in the Santa Rosa parish, Santa Cruz, Galapagos province. Ninety-six, day-old broilers (Cobb 500) of either sex were randomized into three treatment groups with two replicates in each group (16 chicks per replicate). The dietary treatments were a control diet (T1), a diet containing 6% FS (T2), and a diet containing 12% FS (T3). The evaluation period was 46 days. Animals remained in facilities according to what was detailed in the experimental design (Annex 1) and the characteristics evaluated were: feed intake, SF intake, weight gain, and feed conversion ratio (FCR).

b. Summary Statistics
Feed intake, daily weight gain, and FCR were compared across the three treatments. The following statistical analyzes focus on daily weight gain and feed conversion; these parameters were effectively measured for each animal. Feed and FS were weighed and supplied to each replicate (16 animals), so a real estimate of individual consumption could not be obtained. This individual consumption is assumed to be a proportional average of the total food supplied.

The average daily weight gain per animal for the 46 days of the trial was 76.12 \(\pm\) 7.58 g day-1 (n = 29), 72.47 \(\pm\) 6.62 g day-1 (n = 32), 77.41 \(\pm\) 9.65 g day-1 (n = 32), for diets T1, T2, and T3, respectively; values display the daily mean \(\pm\) 1 standard deviation.
The average FCR for the 46 days of the trial was 1.78 \(\pm\) 0.18 g day-1 (n = 29), 1.82 \(\pm\) 0.16 g day-1 (n = 32), 1.63 \(\pm\) 0.2 g day-1 (n = 32), for diets T1, T2, and T3, respectively; values display the mean \(\pm\) 1 standard deviation. c.2. Statistically significant differences
The plots below show the distribution of average weight gain and FCR for the three treatments. A one-way ANOVA was then performed to compare the effect of these three dietary treatments on daily weight gain and FCR. Significant differences were explored using a significance level (\(\alpha\)) of 0.05. The differences between groups were quantified using the effect size (Cohen’s d). If significant differences were demonstrated through the one-way ANOVA, Tukey’s HSD test was used as a post-hoc pairwise test to define between which groups, in particular, these differences were statistically significant.

  geom_boxplot(fill = NA, width = 0.2, outlier.color = NA) +
  stat_summary(fun=mean, 
               geom="point", 
               shape=20, 
               size=4, 
               color="black", 
               fill="black") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(y = "Average daily weight gain (g)",

# Get the effect size: 
gd_t1_t2_effsize <- cohen.d(t1_gd, t2_gd)
gd_t1_t3_effsize <- cohen.d(t1_gd, t3_gd)

ca_t1_t2_effsize <- cohen.d(t1_ca, t2_ca)
ca_t1_t3_effsize <- cohen.d(t1_ca, t3_ca)


#Daily weight gain ANOVA:
gd_anova <- aov(mean_ganancia_diaria ~ tratamiento, data = general_selected_1) #modeling mean CA as a function of treatment (diet)

#Daily weight gain Tukey:
gd_tukey <- TukeyHSD(gd_anova)

#Get results in tidy format:
gd_anova_tidy <- tidy(gd_anova)
gd_tukey_tidy <- tidy(gd_tukey)


#Daily FCR ANOVA:
ca_anova <- aov(mean_ca ~ tratamiento, data = general_selected_1) #modeling mean CA as a function of treatment (diet)

#FCR Tukey:
ca_tukey <- TukeyHSD(ca_anova)

#Get results in tidy format:
ca_anova_tidy <- tidy(ca_anova)
ca_tukey_tidy <- tidy(ca_tukey)


As shown above, the average daily weight gain of the T1 diet is greater than T2 and smaller than T3; 76.12 \(\pm\) 7.58 g day-1, 72.47 \(\pm\) 6.62 g day-1, and 77.41 \(\pm\) 9.65 g day-1, respectively. The absolute difference between T1 and T2 daily weight gain means is 3.65 g day-1 (a 4.91% difference), while between T1 and T3 it is -1.29 g day-1 (a -1.68% difference). These differences are significant; one-way ANOVA: p = 0.04. The effect size between diets T1 and T2 is medium (Cohen’s d = 0.51) and between diets T1 and T3 is negligible (Cohen’s d = -0.15). Applying Tukey’s HSD test to determine if the relationship between the different groups is statistically significant, we saw that there was no statistically significant difference in mean daily weight gains between T1 and T2 (p = 0.19) or between T1 and T3 (p = 0.81). The only significant difference was observed between diets T3 and T2 (p = 0.04).
Mean FCR of diet T1 is lower than T2 and higher than T3; 1.78 \(\pm\) 0.18 g day-1, 1.82 \(\pm\) 0.16 g day-1, and 1.63 \(\pm\) 0.2 g day-1, respectively. The absolute difference between the means of T1 and T2 is -0.04 g day-1 (a -2.08% difference), and between T1 and T3 is 0.15 g day-1 (a 9.26% difference). These differences are significant; one-way ANOVA: p = 10^{-4}. The effect size between diets T1 and T2 is small (Cohen’s d = -0.22), while between diets T1 and T3 is large (Cohen’s d = 0.81). As evidenced by Tukey’s HSD test, the differences in FCR between diets T1 and T3 (p = 0.004) and T2 and T3 (p = 2^{-4}) are statistically significant.
In summary, the effects on average daily weight gain of the control diet (T1) compared to the diets with FS (T2 and T3) are not statistically different. The only significant difference in average daily weight gain is seen between the diets T2 and T3, with the average daily weight gain of diet T3 being 6.6% higher than T2.
The effect of diets with FS on FCR showed significant differences with respect to the control diet. In particular, the difference between T3 and T1 turned out to be large and statistically significant (Cohen’s d = 0.81; Tukey’s HSD p = 0.004). Overall, T3 delivered the best results: higher average daily weight gain and lower FCR.

 

4. Summary
Exploratory data analysis and interpretation of trial results reveal the following findings:
The trial with pigs showed that FS can be successfully used in Galapagos pig production as a feed supplement, achieving similar yields to those obtained with available commercial feeds and without imparting an undesirable flavor to the meat.

title: Parameter Estimation with Nonlinear Least Squares: Wild Fish Catch (1950-2012)
description: In this analysis, I applied nonlinear least squares to estimate parameters for a logistic growth model describing the trend of wild fish catch from 1950 to 2012. The data, sourced from the FAO, showed an initial exponential increase in fish catch over the first 40 years, followed by a plateau. The logistic growth equation was used to model this relationship, with the carrying capacity (K), growth rate constant (k), and initial population parameter (A) estimated through nonlinear least squares fitting. The resulting model accurately captures the trend of wild fish catch over time, providing insights into the dynamics of global fishery resources.
contents:
Data source: Global wild fish catch and aquaculture production, compiled by Earth Policy Institute with 1950-2012 from U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO). Available at: https://www.fao.org/fishery/topic/16140/en
Summary
In this report, I use nonlinear least squares to find parameters for a model describing wild fish catch over time. Data: FAO (2012).


Show code

#Read in data and initial wrangling:
fish_catch <- read_csv("fish_catch.csv", skip=2) %>% 
  slice(-c(66:69)) %>% #keep rows with relevant information for the analysis
  slice(-c(1:2)) %>% 
  clean_names() #names to lowercase


#Add new column with years 0-62 (1950 = 0 / 2012 = 62):
fish_catch_years <- fish_catch %>% 
  mutate(years = 0:(n() - 1)) %>% 
  mutate(wild_catch = as.numeric(wild_catch)) %>% 
  mutate(year = as.numeric(year))




Show code

#Exploratory graph:

ggplot(data = fish_catch_years, aes(x = years, y = wild_catch)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(x = "time (years)", y = "wild fish catch (Mt)") +
  theme_minimal()


Show code

#Log transformed data:
#ggplot(data = fish_catch_years, aes(x = years, y = log(wild_catch))) +
  #geom_point() +
  #labs(x = "time (years)", y = "ln(wild fish catch)") +
  #theme_minimal()


The exploratory graph describes a logistic relationship. In the first 40 years (1950-1990) wild fish catch increases exponentially and then remain relatively constant near 94 Mt.
The logistic growth equation describes this relationship:
\(P(t)=\frac{K}{1+Ae^{-kt}}\)
\(K\) is the carrying capacity
\(A\) is \(\frac{K-P_0}{P_0}\)
\(k\) is the growth rate constant


Show code

#Initial estimates for the parameters in the model:

##Estimate the growth constant during exponential phase (to get a starting-point guess for *k*):

### Get the first 40 years (exponential growth) and log transform the population to estimate the growth rate constant (k) during this exponential growth:
fish_catch_exp <- fish_catch_years %>% 
  filter(years < 40) %>% 
  mutate(ln_wild_catch = log(wild_catch))


### Make a linear model to get the slope (slope = growth rate constant *k*):
lm_fish_catch <- lm(ln_wild_catch ~ years, data = fish_catch_exp)

lm_fish_catch 
# slope: (k) ~ 0.0356


### Initial estimates: # k = 0.356 
                       # K = 94
                       # A = (K-P0)/P0 = 4.5


Nonlinear least squares


Show code

#Nonlinear least squares to find parameter for the model describing wild catch:
fish_catch_nls <- nls(wild_catch ~ K/(1 + A*exp(-k*years)),
              data = fish_catch_years,
              start = list(K = 94, 
                           A = 4.5, 
                           k = 0.356),
              trace = TRUE
              )


#Model summary:
summary(fish_catch_nls)



#Report the parameter outcomes (with units) in text or a table:

## Model outputs in tidy format: 
fish_catch_out <- broom::tidy(fish_catch_nls) 
  #View(fish_catch_out)

  #In line references:
      # K = `r round(fish_catch_out$estimate[1],2)`
      # A = `r round(fish_catch_out$estimate[2],2)` 
      # k = `r round(fish_catch_out$estimate[3],4)`


Estimated parameters:
K = 100.28 Mt
A = 4.32 Mt
k = 0.0699 year-1
Model with estimated parameters:
\(P(t) = \frac{100.28}{1+4.32e^{-0.699t}}\)


Show code

#Finalized graph showing original data and model output:

## Make predictions for wild catch for all of the years: 
fish_catch_predict <- predict(fish_catch_nls)

## Add predictions to data:
fish_catch_comp <- data.frame(fish_catch_years, fish_catch_predict)

# Plot them all together:
ggplot(data = fish_catch_comp) +
  geom_point(aes(x = year, y = wild_catch)) +
  geom_line(aes(x = year, y = fish_catch_predict), color = "dodgerblue2") +
  labs(x = "year", y = "wild fish catch (Mt)") +
  geom_text(aes(x = 1978,y = 65, label= "Model output", hjust = 1), size = 2.5, color = "dodgerblue2")+
  theme_minimal()

title: Spatial Data Visualization of CA 2008 Oil Spill Events
description: In this analysis, I explored the spatial distribution of oil spill events in California during 2008 using spatial data visualization techniques. The analysis involved creating an interactive map to display the locations of inland and marine oil spill incidents, allowing for detailed exploration of the data. Additionally, I produced a static choropleth map to illustrate the distribution of inland oil spill events by county, using color gradients to represent the frequency of incidents. This approach provided insights into the geographic patterns of oil spills across California, highlighting areas with higher concentrations of incidents.
contents:
Data source: California Department of Fish and Wildlife (CDFW), Office of Spill Prevention and Response (OSPR). (2009). Oil Spill Incident Tracking, 2008. California Department of Fish and Wildlife. Available at: https://map.dfg.ca.gov/metadata/ds0394.html
Summary
In this report, I explore the spatial distribution of oil spill events in California in 2008. First, I make an interactive map showing the location of inland and marine oil spill incidents. Then, I examine the distribution of inland oil spill events and make a static chloropleth map displaying counts of inland spill incidents by county. Data: CDFW (2009).


Show code

# Read in data, update col names, and check projection:


#Read in Oil Spill Incident Tracking data and update col names to lowercase:
oil_spill <- read_sf("Oil_Spill_Incident_Tracking_%5Bds394%5D-shp", layer = "Oil_Spill_Incident_Tracking_%5Bds394%5D") %>% 
  clean_names() %>% 
  rename(Location = inlandmari) #rename col showing spill location

# Check Oil Spill Incident Tracking data projection:
#st_crs(oil_spill) # WGS 84 (EPSG,3857)


# Read in the CA county data, update col names to lowercase, and keep only names:
ca_counties <- read_sf("ca_counties", layer = "CA_Counties_TIGER2016") %>% 
  clean_names() %>% 
  select(name) 

# Check the CA county projection
  #st_crs(ca_counties) # WGS 84 (EPSG,3857)
    #Same Projection as Oil Spill Incident Tracking data (no need to set or transform CRS)


Exploratory interactive map of oil spill events


Show code

# Check data with a quick ggplot:
#ggplot() +
  #geom_sf(data = ca_counties) +
  #geom_sf(data = oil_spill, aes(color = Location), size = 0.5)

#Interactive plot (tmap)
tmap_mode("view")

tm_shape(oil_spill) +
  tm_dots("Location") 



Figure 1. Oil spill events in California in 2008. Events are divided based on location. Green and yellow points indicate inland and marine event locations, respectively. Data: CDFW (2009).
Static chloropleth map showing counts of inland oil spill events by county


Show code

#Only keep inland oil spills:
inland_oil_spill <- oil_spill %>% 
  filter(Location == "Inland")

#Spatial join of data:
ca_oil_spill <- ca_counties %>%
  st_join(inland_oil_spill)

#Counts of inland oil spills by county:
oil_spill_counts <- ca_oil_spill %>% 
  count(name)
#oil_spill_subset

#Static chloropleth map:
ggplot(data = oil_spill_counts) +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = n), color = "white", size = 0.1) +
  scale_fill_gradientn(colors = c("lightsalmon1","orangered1","red4")) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(fill = "Inland oil spills (2008)")



Figure 2. Counts of California’s inland oil spill events by county in 2008. County color, from salmon to dark red, reflects the number of inland oil spill incidents. Data: CDFW (2009).

title: Hierarchical Multivariate Clustering for Water Stream Chemistry by Site (Santa Barbara Coastal Drainage Area)
description: In this analysis, I applied hierarchical clustering using complete linkage to explore the multivariate relationships in water stream chemistry across different sites in the Santa Barbara coastal drainage area. The resulting dendrogram visually represents the clustering of sites based on their chemical composition, with clusters formed according to the multivariate similarity between sites. This approach helps to identify groups of sites with similar water chemistry, providing insights into the spatial patterns of stream chemistry in the region.
contents:
Data source: Santa Barbara Coastal LTER and J. Melack. 2019. SBC LTER: Land: Stream chemistry in the Santa Barbara Coastal drainage area, ongoing since 2000 ver 16. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/67a558a24ceed9a0a5bf5e46ab841174.
Summary
In this analysis, I use hierarchical clustering by complete linkage to create a dendrogram showing multivariate clustering for water stream chemistry by site in the Santa Barbara coastal drainage area. Data: Santa Barbara Coastal LTER and Melack (2019).


Show code

#Read in data:
stream_chem_sb <- read_csv("sbc_lter_registered_stream_chemistry.csv") %>% 
  replace_with_na_all(condition = ~.x == -999) #rename missing values (-999) as NA




Show code

#Data wrangling:
stream_chem_mean <- stream_chem_sb %>%
  #group by site
  group_by(site_code) %>% 
  #set new columns with mean values
  summarise(mean_nh4 = mean(nh4_uM, na.rm = TRUE), 
            mean_no3 = mean(no3_uM, na.rm = TRUE),
            mean_po4 = mean(po4_uM, na.rm = TRUE),
            mean_tdn = mean(tdn_uM, na.rm = TRUE),
            mean_tdp = mean(tdp_uM, na.rm = TRUE),
            mean_tpc = mean(tpc_uM, na.rm = TRUE),
            mean_tpn = mean(tpn_uM, na.rm = TRUE),
            mean_tpp = mean(tpp_uM, na.rm = TRUE),
            mean_tss = mean(tss_mgperLiter, na.rm = TRUE),
            mean_spec_cond = mean(spec_cond_uSpercm, na.rm = TRUE) 
    ) %>% 
  #exclude rows with missing data
  na.omit() 

#Scale data (columns 2:11):
stream_chem_scale <- stream_chem_mean %>%   
  select(2:11) %>% 
  scale()

# Add sites as rownames from stream_chem_mea:
rownames(stream_chem_scale) <- stream_chem_mean$site_code




Show code

#Get the Euclidean distance with `stats::dist()`:
stream_chem_euc_dist <- dist(stream_chem_scale, method = "euclidean")




Show code

# Complete linkage agglomerative hierarchical clustering with `stats::hclust()`:

## Hierarchical clustering (complete linkage):
stream_chem_hc_comp <- hclust(stream_chem_euc_dist, method = "complete" )

## Plots:

###Base plot:
    #plot(stream_chem_hc_comp, cex = 0.6, hang = -1)

### Ggdendogram:
ggdendrogram(stream_chem_hc_comp, 
             rotate = TRUE) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "Site Code",
       y = "")



Figure 1. Complete linkage agglomerative hierarchical clustering for water stream chemistry by site in the Santa Barbara coastal drainage area. Black lines show the grouping of sites into clusters based on multivariate similarity. Data: Santa Barbara Coastal LTER and Melack (2019).

title: Spatial Distribution of 35 Cetacean Species off the Coast of California
description: In this analysis, I explored the spatial distribution of 35 cetacean species along the California coast using predicted range maps generated by AquaMaps. The analysis involved calculating species richness based on the probability of occurrence, which was determined by the relative environmental suitability and species preferences for factors such as water temperature, depth, salinity, and proximity to land. A threshold value of 0.6 or higher for the probability of occurrence was used to classify species as "present." The results were visualized on a static map, with a color gradient representing the number of species categorized as "present" in each area.
contents:
Data source: Kaschner, K., Rius-Barile, J., Kesner-Reyes, K., Garilao, C., Kullander, S., Rees, T., & Froese, R. (2016). AquaMaps: Predicted range maps for aquatic species. Available at: https://www.aquamaps.org
Summary
In this report, I explore the spatial distribution of 35 cetacean species off the coast of California. Species richness was obtained from the probability of occurrence, which, in turn, is determined based on the relative environmental suitability and species preferences for water temperature, depth, salinity, and distance to land. A threshold value for the probability of occurrence of 0.6 or higher was taken to classify species as “present”. Results are displayed on a static map of the California coast.


Show code

#Rasterizing all layers together with `raster::stack()`:
ca_cet <- raster::stack(list.files(path = "ca_cetaceans", pattern = ".tif", full.names = TRUE))

#Check raster info and initial plot: 
  #ca_cet
  #plot(ca_cet)


Species richness of 35 cetacean species off the coast of California


Show code

#Convert to data frame:
ca_cet_df <- raster::rasterToPoints(ca_cet) %>%
  as.data.frame()

#Data wrangling:
ca_cet_wrang <- ca_cet_df %>%
  pivot_longer(!1:2,  names_to = "species", values_to = "prob") %>%
  mutate(presence =  case_when(prob >= "0.6" ~ 1,
                               TRUE ~ 0)) #classify species as "present" based on threshold for the probability of occurrence of 0.6 or higher 


#Counts species "present" (prob >= 0.6):
ca_cet_counts <- ca_cet_wrang %>% 
  group_by(x,y) %>% 
  summarise(counts = sum(presence))
#ca_cet_counts

#Download US map as sf (rnaturalearth package):
usa_sf <- ne_states(country = "united states of america", returnclass = "sf")




Show code

#Plot (raster + sf):
ggplot() +
  geom_raster(data = ca_cet_counts, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = counts))+ #rater of species counts
  geom_sf(data = usa_sf, color = "white",  fill = "gray24")+ # US sf map ("large")
  coord_sf(xlim = c(-125, -115), ylim = c(32, 38), expand = FALSE) + #set boundaries of the map matching the raster
  scale_fill_gradientn(colors = c("gray97","skyblue1","dodgerblue4")) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "", y = "", 
       fill = "Cetacean species counts")



Figure 1. Species richness of 35 cetacean species off the coast of California. Presence of cetacean species was determined based on the probability of occurrence; a threshold value for the probability of occurrence of 0.6 or higher was taken to classify species as “present”. Spatial distribution of the color gradient, from light blue to dark blue, reflects the number of species categorized as “present” in each area. Data: Kaschner et al. (2016).

title: Seasonality Trends of Coho, Jack Coho Salmon, and Steelhead Trout in the Columbia River Basin (2000-2010)
description: In this analysis, we explored the seasonal migration trends of Steelhead trout, Coho salmon, and Jack-Coho salmon as they passed through the Willamette Falls fish ladder in Oregon, using data from 2000 to 2010. The analysis involved time series visualization to capture the temporal trends for each species and seasonal plots to illustrate the variation within each year. The findings revealed distinct seasonal migratory patterns, with all three species showing peak presence in the fall. The time series analysis indicated that Steelhead trout numbers remained relatively stable, while Coho and Jack-Coho salmon populations displayed an increasing trend over the studied period.
contents:
Show code

#INITIAL WRANGLING:

#Read in data and update to lower case:
willamette_fish_passage <- read_csv("willamette_fish_passage.csv")%>% 
  clean_names()

#Mutate date to class "Date" and convert data to time series data frame (tsibble):
willamette_ts <- willamette_fish_passage %>% 
  mutate(date = mdy(date)) %>%
  as_tsibble(key = NULL, index = date)



Willamette Falls in June 2012 | Credit: Peggy Sigler
Overview
Here we look at the seasonal variation in passage of Steelhead trout, Coho salmon, and Jack-Coho salmon through the Willamette Falls fish ladder in Williamette, Oregon. Our analysis displays the varying seasonal trends for each of these three species as well as changes over time, looking at data from 2001-2010. This provides important insights into the population dynamics of all three species, which are of great ecological, cultural and economic value.

Columbia River Basin salmon run map | Credit: www.bpa.gov
Data source: Columbia Basin Research, School of Aquatic & Fishery Sciences, University of Washington; additional data courtesy of U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, NWD and Chelan, Douglas, and Grant County PUDs, Yakima Klickitat Fisheries Project, Colville Tribes Fish & Wildlife (OBMEP), Oregon Department of Fish & Wildlife, Washington Department of Fish & Wildlife (2021).
Fish passage at the Willamette Falls, Willamette River (Oregon)
Tab 1: Time Series of Fish Passage


Show code

# Read in data
fish_data <- read_csv("willamette_fish_passage.csv") %>% 
  clean_names()

# Select for coho, jack coho and steelhead
fish_clean <- fish_data %>% 
  select("date", "steelhead", "coho", "jack_coho") %>% 
  mutate(across(where(is.numeric), ~ ifelse(is.na(.), 0, .))) %>% 
  mutate(date = mdy(date)) %>% 
  mutate(year = year(date))




Show code

# Wrangle data in preparation for time series
fish_ts <- fish_clean %>% 
  mutate(yearmonth = yearmonth(date)) %>% 
  as_tibble(key = NULL, index = yearmonth) 




Show code

# Steelhead salmon
ggplot(data = fish_ts, aes(x = date, y = steelhead, color = steelhead)) +
  geom_line(color = "palegreen4") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Steelhead Salmon", title = "Steelhead Trout Passage over Time")



Figure 1: This time series reveals the trend in steelhead salmon migration through the Columbia River from 2000 to 2010.Data: Columbia River DART (Data Access in Real Time).





Show code

# Coho slamon
ggplot(data = fish_ts, aes(x = date, y = coho, color = coho)) +
  geom_line(color = "red3") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Coho Salmon", title = "Coho Salmon Passage over Time")



Figure 2: This time series reveals the trend in coho salmon migration through the Columbia River from 2000 to 2010.Data: Columbia River DART (Data Access in Real Time).





Show code

# Jack Coho salmon
ggplot(data = fish_ts, aes(x = date, y = jack_coho, color = jack_coho)) +
  geom_line(color = "orange1") +
  theme_minimal()+
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Jack Coho Salmon", title = "Jack Coho Salmon Passage over Time")



Figure 3: This time series reveals the trend in jack coho salmon migration through the Columbia River from 2000 to 2010.Data: Columbia River DART (Data Access in Real Time).



From the times series graphs on steelhead trout, coho and jack coho salmon, we can see that:
All three species have strong, seasonal migratory patterns through the Columbia River. Each species appears to have a strong presence later in the year - during the fall.
Steelhead trout numbers have remained relatively constant and are predicted to remain constant through 2030 while coho and jack coho salmon numbers are expected to increase.
Steelhead trout spend a greater time on average in the Columbia River than do either of the other two species.
Tab 2: Season Plots


Show code

willamette_long <- willamette_ts %>% 
  pivot_longer(cols = chinook_run:pink, 
               names_to = "species", 
               values_to = "counts") %>% 
  filter(species %in% c("coho", "jack_coho", "steelhead"))


coho_season <- willamette_long %>% 
  filter(species == "coho") %>% 
  gg_season(y = counts, 
            period = "year", 
            show.legend = FALSE)+
  ylim(0,1000)+
  theme_minimal()+
  labs(x= "", y = "", title = "Coho Salmon")

#coho_season

jack_coho_season <- willamette_long %>% 
  filter(species == "jack_coho") %>% 
  gg_season(y = counts, 
            period = "year")+
  theme_minimal()+
  ylim(0,1000)+
  labs(x= "", 
       y = "Number of Observations", title = "Jack-Coho Salmon")

#jack_coho_season


steelhead_season <- willamette_long %>% 
  filter(species == "steelhead") %>% 
  gg_season(y = counts, 
            period = "year", 
            show.legend = FALSE)+
  theme_minimal()+
  ylim(0,1000)+
  labs(x= "Month", y = "", title = "Steelhead Trout") 

#steelhead_season

# compound_season <- willamette_long %>% 
#   gg_season(y = counts, 
#             period = "year")+
#   facet_wrap(~species)+
#   theme_minimal()
# 
# compound_season

patch_season <- (coho_season/jack_coho_season/steelhead_season)+
  plot_annotation(title = "Coho, Jack-Coho, and Steelhead Seasonal Abundance in Willamette Falls (2001-2010)")

patch_season



Figure 4: Abundance of Coho, Jack-Coho and Steelhead seasonally observed in at Willamette Falls fish ladder Willamette, Oregon. These observations range from 2001-2010.Year is indicated by color. Data: Columbia River DART (Data Access in Real Time).



From the season plots on steelhead trout, coho and jack coho salmon, we can see that:
- Coho and Jack-Coho are consistently at peak abundance in October, with at least small numbers of individuals present from August to November.
The number of Coho observed seems to have increased in recent years.
Observations of Steelhead are more diffuse throughout the year with the most observations ranging from February to July.
Tab 3: Annual Counts by Species


Show code

willamette_fish_annual <- willamette_fish_passage %>%
  mutate(date = mdy(date)) %>%
  mutate(date_year = year(date)) 

coho_annual <- willamette_fish_annual %>%
  count(date_year, wt = coho)
jack_coho_annual <- willamette_fish_annual %>%
  count(date_year, wt = jack_coho)
steelhead_annual <- willamette_fish_annual %>%
  count(date_year, wt = steelhead)

 

ggplot()+ 
  geom_line(data = coho_annual, aes(x = date_year, y = n, color = "Coho"), size = 0.7) +
  geom_line(data = jack_coho_annual, aes(x = date_year, y = n, color = "Jack Coho"), size = 0.7) +
  geom_line(data = steelhead_annual, aes(x = date_year, y = n, color = "Steelhead"), size = 0.7) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks=c(2001, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010), limits = c(2001,2010)) + 
  scale_color_manual(values = c( "Coho" = "red3", "Jack Coho" = "orange1", "Steelhead" = "palegreen4"))+
  labs(color = "Species")+
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::label_number(scale_cut = scales::cut_si("")))+
  labs(x = "Year",
       y = "Counts",
       title = "Annual counts by Species, Willamette Falls (2001-2010)") +
  theme_minimal()



Figure 5: Annual counts by species at the Willamette Falls fish ladder, Willamette River, Oregon (2001-2010). Red, orange, and green lines indicate counts for the species coho, jack coho, and steelhead, respectively. Data: Columbia River DART (Data Access in Real Time).



Summary
Annual counts of coho, jack coho, and steelhead species on the Willamette Falls fish ladder (2001-2010) show the following major trends:
An overall low number of the jack coho species for the entire time period 2001-2010
A marked increase in the counts of individuals of the coho species for the years 2009-2010
A high number of individuals of the steelhead species for the period 2001-2004 followed by a relative decrease in the years 2005-2009 and a recent increase in the year 2010

title: Macronutrients and Energy Content in Beef Products, Pork Products, and Poultry Products
description: In this analysis, I explored the relationship between protein, carbohydrate, fat, and energy content in three food groups (Beef Products, Pork Products, and Poultry Products) using Principal Components Analysis (PCA). PCA is a statistical technique used to reduce the dimensionality of multivariate data while retaining as much information as possible. This allows for easier visualization and identification of patterns, relationships, and outliers. The results were visualized using a biplot, where the first two principal components explained 80% of the variance in the data, revealing strong correlations between certain macronutrients and the distinct clustering of food groups.
contents:
Introduction
In this report, I explore the variables protein, carbohydrate, fat, and energy content in three different food groups (Beef Products, Pork Products, and Poultry Products) by performing a Principal Components Analysis (PCA) and reflecting this information on a biplot. PCA is an ordination method used to visualize patterns in multivariate data that allows to reframe multivariate data in a simplified number of dimensions while retaining as much information as possible. This way, PCA enables us to easily explore the relationship between the variables and identify multivariate patterns and outliers.
Data for this report was taken from the USDA National Nutrient Database (https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/).






Figure 1. Biplot of the PCA ordination performed for the variables protein, carbohydrate, fat, and energy content in three different food groups. Orange dots represent observations for Beef Products, blue squares for Pork Products, and green triangles for Poultry Products. Their position reflects the score of each observation based on the principal components (PC1 and PC2). Distance between observations approximate the Euclidean distance and allow assessing similarity in multivariate space and identifying multivariate groups and outliers. Arrows show the loading of variables for each principal component (PC1 and PC2). Their length indicates variance in the principal component direction (PC1 horizontal component and PC2 vertical component); the angle between them shows the variables correlation. Data USDA (2019).
Summary
Displayed PCA biplot describes 80% of variance in the analyzed data (PC1 55% and PC2 25%). The arrows convey information about the examined variables. The small angle separating the variables fat and energy reveals a strong positive correlation between them. In turn, these variables are negatively correlated with protein and not highly correlated with carbohydrates (almost right angle). At the same time, the distribution of observation in the biplot enables recognizing multivariate groups and outliers. Here we can observe a big cluster of multivariate similar observations in the center of the biplot and some outlier observations extending vertically (poultry products) and horizontally (mainly beef and pork products).
Citation:
U.S. Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service. FoodData Central, 2019. https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/

title: Bootstrapped Confidence Interval for Proportions
description: In this analysis, I applied bootstrapping to estimate the confidence interval for the proportion of nonbinary/genderqueer UCSB community members who reported experiencing “exclusionary, offensive, hostile or intimidating conduct.” Using data from the UCSB Campus Climate Project, I calculated the proportion of respondents who reported such experiences and generated 100,000 bootstrap samples to create a distribution of proportions. The resulting 95% confidence interval for the bootstrapped distribution provides a robust estimate of the true proportion, offering insights into the prevalence of these experiences within the community.
contents:
Data source: UCSB Campus Climate Project Final Report (2014). Prepared by Rankin & Associates Consulting. Available at:
http://campusclimate.ucop.edu/_common/files/pdf-climate/ucsb-full-report.pdf
Summary
In this report, I use data from a survey of UCSB community members in which 22 out of 36 individuals identified as nonbinary/genderqueer responded that they had personally experienced “exclusionary, offensive,
hostile or intimidating conduct” and applying bootstrapping I find the confidence interval for the bootstrapped distribution. Data: UCSB Campus Climate Project Final Report (2014).


Show code

#Vector of UCSB community members identified as nonbinary/genderqueer responds:
  # n = 36
  # 22/36 = "1" (personally experienced “exclusionary, offensive, hostile or intimidating conduct”)
  # 14/36 = "0" (didn't experience “exclusionary, offensive, hostile or intimidating conduct”)

ucsb_resp <- rep(c(1, 0),times=c(22, 14)) 




Show code

#Create a function that calculates the proportion of UCSB community members identified as nonbinary/genderqueer who responded that they had personally experienced “exclusionary, offensive, hostile or intimidating conduct”

prop <- function (x, i) {
  sum(x[i])/length(x[i])
}


##Test function:
#prop(ucsb_resp)
   #result = 0.61




Show code

# Create 100,000 bootstrap samples by resampling ucsb_resp vector and use the prop() function to calculate the respond proportions on each:
set.seed(1) #specify random number seed
ucsb_resp_100k <- boot(ucsb_resp, 
                       statistic = prop, 
                       R = 100000)
  
# Check the output:  
#ucsb_resp_100k




Show code

#Histogram of bootsrapped proportions:

## Make a data frame with the vectors of bootstrap sample proportions: 
ucsb_resp_100k_df <- data.frame(uscb_resp_prop = ucsb_resp_100k$t)

## Histogram plot:
 ggplot(data = ucsb_resp_100k_df, aes(x = uscb_resp_prop)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 25) +
   theme_minimal()+
   labs(x = "Boostrapped proportions (nonbinary individuals that experienced exclusionary conduct)")



Figure 1. Histogram of bootstrap proportions (100,000 bootstrap samples from an original sample n = 36) for nonbinary/genderqueer UCSB community members that had personally experienced “exclusionary, offensive, hostile or intimidating conduct”. Data: UCSB Campus Climate Project Final Report (2014).


Show code

#Use bootstrapped sampling distribution to find the confidence interval:

ucsb_resp_100k_ci <- boot.ci(ucsb_resp_100k, conf = 0.95)

#results:
ucsb_resp_100k_ci


The proportion of UCSB community members identifying as nonbinary/genderqueer who responded that they had personally experienced “exclusionary, offensive, hostile or intimidating conduct” is 0.61 (n = 36), with a bootstrapped 95% confidence interval of [0.45, 0.77] (n = 100,000 bootstrap samples). Data: UCSB Campus Climate Project Final Report (2014).

title: Relationships Between Selected Black-throated Blue Warbler Characteristics and Mass
description: In this analysis, I investigated the relationships between various characteristics of black-throated blue warblers and their mass using multiple linear regression. The analysis began with exploratory visualizations, including scatterplots and beeswarm plots, to identify potential linear relationships and outliers. Then, I performed multiple linear regression to quantitatively describe the relationships between mass and other recorded features such as wing length, sex, bill dimensions, and tarsus length. Model selection was based on diagnostic plots, Adjusted R-squared, and AIC scores to ensure the best balance between model fit and complexity.
contents:
Summary
In this report, I explore the relationships between selected
black-throated blue warbler characteristics and mass. First, I visually
explore the data. Then, I use multiple linear regression to describe the
relationship.



1. Exploratory Visualization
Exploratory scatterplots exploring linear relationship (also
useful for identifying notable outliers and having some initial thoughts
about homoscedasticity)
Beeswarm plot for visualizing the relationship between bird mass
and elevation of the sample plot (low, mid, or high)



2. Multiple linear regression
Exploring
relationships between bird mass (dependent variable) and other recorded
features (explanatory variables)



Comparing the different
models:
Observation of how the coefficients change in the different
models as predictor variables change
Assessment of model fit (Adjusted R-squared)
Diagnostic plots for exploring model assumptions
(homoscedasticity and distribution of residuals and Cook’s
distance)
Comparison of the quality (balance: model fit / complexity) of
the different models (AIC)
Selected model outcomes

Note:

Justification of the model
selection
Diagnostic plots for exploring model assumptions reveal normally
distributed and homoscedastic residuals for all models. In the evaluated
models, Adjusted R-squared (a measure of how much the variance in the
dependent variable is explained by the explanatory variables in the
model) increases with the addition of more predictor variables. AIC
shows comparative scores reflecting the balance between the predictive
capabilities of the model (model fit) and the increase in complexity due
to the addition of variables. When comparing the initial models, the
model with the highest number of variables (lm5) showed the best balance
in model fit/complexity (i.e., the benefits in model fit of adding the
additional variables outweigh the increased complexity). However, as the
addition of the age_banded variable determined an increase in the AIC, I
decided to try a new model (lm6) by removing this variable from the lm5
model. Showing a better balance between model fit and complexity (lower
AIC), lm6 was the selected model.
Interpretation of lm6
coefficients
Wing length coefficient (wing_r 0.071): on average, a 1 mm
increase in wing length is associated with a 0.071 g increase in bird
mass.
Sex coefficient (sexM -1.038): on average, if everything else is
fixed, we expect males to have a 1.038 g less mass than females
(reference level).
Bill cross-section depth coefficient (bill_depth 0.112): on
average, a 1 mm increase in bill cross-section depth is associated with
a 0.112 g increase in bird mass.
Bill culmen length coefficient (bill_culmen 0.138): on average, a
1 mm increase in bill culmen length is associated with a 0.138 g
increase in bird mass.
Tarsus length coefficient (tarsus1 0.061): on average, a 1 mm
increase in tarsus length is associated with a 0.061 g increase in bird
mass.

Experimental Forest, 1986 - 2010 ver 4. Environmental Data Initiative.

title: Exploration of Data for Marine Turtles of Species Green and Loggerhead Captured in Shark Bay, Australia
description: In this analysis, I explored the relationship between carapace length and width in green and loggerhead turtles through data visualization and linear regression, which quantitatively described this relationship. A strong positive correlation was found, with 93% of the variance in carapace width being explained by length. Additionally, I compared the carapace lengths between green and loggerhead turtles using a two-sample t-test, which showed no significant difference in mean lengths between the species. Finally, I assessed the association between species and the occurrence of burrowing barnacles using a chi-square test, revealing a significant association between the two variables.
contents:
Summary
In this report, I explore the relationship between sea turtle
carapace length and width by visualizing the data and performing linear
regression to quantitative describe this relationship. Then, I
statistically compare the carapace lengths between green and loggerhead
turtles. For this comparison I perform a two-sample t-tests
(significance level (\(\alpha\)) of
0.05). Lastly, I explore the association between species (green and
loggerhead) and the occurrence of burrowing barnacles through a
chi-square test.



1.
Relationship between sea turtle carapace length and width
Exploratory visualization



Linear
regression: quantitative description of the relationship between sea
turtle carapace length and width


Call:
lm(formula = width ~ length, data = sea_turtles)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-16.4171  -2.1140  -0.0254   2.2046   9.9637 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)  5.95970    1.29609   4.598 6.46e-06 ***
length       0.86214    0.01396  61.775  < 2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 3.396 on 280 degrees of freedom
  (1 observation deleted due to missingness)
Multiple R-squared:  0.9316,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.9314 
F-statistic:  3816 on 1 and 280 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


There is a linear relationship between sea turtles’ carapace length
(cm) and width (cm). Linear model summary: \(\beta\)1 = 0.86 cm
cm-1, p < 0.001, R2 = 0.93, Pearson’s
r = 0.97).
This summary shows that, on average, we expect carapace width to
increase by 0.86 centimeter for each one centimeter increase in length.
At the same time, the R2 shows that 93.16% of the variance in
carapace width is predictable from the length. Carapace length and width
are strongly, and significantly, positively correlated (Pearson’s
r = 0.97, p < 0.001). Diagnostic plots (not included) show
normally distributed and homoscedastic residuals.
2.
Comparison of carapace lengths between green and loggerhead turtles
Exploratory
visualization of distribution



Bell-shaped histogram reflecting a normal distribution (slightly
positive skew for both green and loggerhead turtles). This normal
distribution is also shown by the quantile-quantile plot with a nearly
linear relationship.
Test
selection: statistically compare carapace lengths for green and
loggerhead turtles
For comparing the carapace lengths for green and loggerhead turtles I
will perform a 2-sample t-test. With this test we can compare the means
of the two groups and know the probability of having obtained sample
means at least this different if they were drawn from populations with
the same mean (p-value). The selection of this test is based on the fact
that thanks to the histograms and quantile-quantile plots we can see
that we satisfy the assumptions about distribution, where carapace
lengths for green and loggerhead turtles follow a relatively normal
distribution (bell-shaped histogram and quantile-quantile plot with an
almost linear relationship). In case of not satisfying this assumption,
we could use a rank-based alternative (Mann-Whitney U test).
2-Sample T-Test



On average, carapace length of green turtles is slightly greater than
that of loggerhead turtles (92.64 \(\pm\) 15.78 and 89.91 \(\pm\) 11.44 cm, respectively; mean \(\pm\) 1 standard deviation). The absolute
difference in means is 2.73cm (a 2.98% difference). The effect size is
negligible (Cohen’s d = 0.19) and the difference in means
(significance level (\(\alpha\)) of
0.05) is not significant (Welch two-sample t-test: t(244.17) = 1.65, p =
9.98e-02).
3.
Comparison of the the occurrence of burrowing barnacles on green versus
loggerhead turtles.
Contingency
table containing the counts and proportions of each species with and
without burrowing barnacles observed
Table 1. Counts and proportions of green and
loggerhead turtles with (Yes) and without (No) burrowing barnacles.
Data: Heithaus & Thomson (2019).


Species


No


Yes


green


87% (164)


13% (24)


loggerhead


69% (66)


31% (29)


Chi-square
test for assessing associationn between species (green and loggerhead)
and the occurrence of burrowing barnacles



For green turtles, burrowing barnacles were present in 24 individuals
and absent in 164. For loggerhead turtles, the presence/absence of
burrowing barnacles was 29 and 66 respectively. There is a significant
association between species (green or loggerhead) and presence/absence
of burrowing barnacles. In other words, species and occurrence of
burrowing barnacles are non-independent (\(\chi\)2(1) = 11.94, p =
5.5e-04).
Citation
Heithaus, M. and J. Thomson. 2019. Marine turtles captured during
haphazard at-sea surveys in Shark Bay, Australia from February 2008 to
December 2013 ver 4. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/7696e20214fbf84f25d664ff7dc8050c

title: Trends in Steller Sea Lion Pup Populations for Five Alaskan Rookeries
description: In this analysis, I explored trends in Steller sea lion pup populations across five Alaskan rookeries (Sugarloaf, Marmot, Forrester Complex, Chowiet, and Hazy). The analysis involved data wrangling to calculate the mean pup counts by site and year, followed by data visualization to examine the population trends over time. The visual exploration revealed a decline in pup populations at Sugarloaf, Marmot, and Chowiet since 1980, while Hazy showed an increase. The Forrester Complex also showed an overall increase, but a notable drop in 2002 requires further investigation.
contents:
Summary
In this report I explore the trends in Steller sea lion pup
populations for five Alaskan rookeries (Sugarloaf, Marmot, Forrester
Complex, Chowiet, and Hazy). First, I wrangle the data to get the mean
value of pup counts by site and year. Second, I visually explore the
trends for each site.



Data wrangling:
Find the mean value of pup counts by site and year
Only keep observations from sites Sugarloaf, Marmot, Forrester
Complex, Chowiet, and Hazy
Only columns containing the site name, year, and pup
count
Rename pup counts as steller_pups






Data Visualization



Figure 1. Steller sea lion pup populations per year
for five Alaskan rookeries (Sugarloaf, Marmot, Forrester Complex,
Chowiet, and Hazy). Blue points indicate recorded counts of Steller sea
lion pups. In the case that several counts were recorded for the same
year, the plotted value represents the mean of those recorded counts.
Data: Fritz et al. (2015).
Trends
in Steller sea lion pup populations for the five Alaskan rookeries
Charts show a decline in Steller sea lion pup populations from 1980
onwards for the sites Sugarloaf, Marmot, and Chowiet. In contrast, Hazy
records an increase in pups population. Forrester Complex shows an
increase in pup counts since 1980, however, a 2002 record of 0 pups is
confusing. More analysis is required to explain this sudden drop in
population.
Citation
Fritz, Lowell; Sweeney, Kathryn; Lynn, Morgan; Gelatt, Thomas;
Gilpatrick, James; Towell, Rodney (2015). Counts of Alaska Steller sea
lion pups conducted on rookeries in Alaska from 1961-06-22 to 2015-07-18
(NCEI Accession 0128189). NOAA National Centers for Environmental
Information. Dataset. https://doi.org/10.7289/v5862ddr.

title: Comparison of Total Length for Female Lizards of Species CNTE and CNUN
description: In this analysis, I compared the total length of female lizards from two species: CNTE (Cnemidophorus tessalatus, the Colorado Checkered lizard) and CNUN (Cnemidophorus uniparens, the Desert Grassland lizard). Using data collected from the Jornada Basin LTER between 1989 and 2006, I employed a two-sample t-test to assess the significance of the difference in total length between the two species, and quantified the effect size using Cohen’s d. The analysis revealed that CNTE females are significantly longer on average than CNUN females, with a large effect size.
contents:
Introduction
This report provides a comparison of the total length for female
lizards of the species CNTE (Cnemidophorus tessalatus, the Colorado
Checkered lizard) and CNUN (Cnemidophorus uniparens, the Desert
Grassland lizard). Data was colected at Jornada Basin Long Term
Ecological Research (LTER) from 1989 to 2006 using pitfall traps that
were checked once a week at the minimum (Lightfoot, 2017). Following
exploratory data visualization, total length of female lizards from the
species CNTE and CNUN were compared by a two-sample t-tests
(significance level (\(\alpha\)) of
0.05) and differences were described by Cohen’s d effect size.
All analyses are in R version 4.0.2 using RStudio version 1.3.1056.






Figure 1. Total lengths (mm) of female lizards of
the species CNTE (Cnemidophorus tessalatus, the Colorado Checkered
lizard) and CNUN (Cnemidophorus uniparens, the Desert Grassland lizard).
Orange (CNTE, Cnemidophorus tessalatus) and teal (CNUN, Cnemidophorus
uniparens) points indicate individual observations for total length
(millimeters) of female lizards. Box endpoints indicate the
25th and 75th percentile values. The black line
and black point within the box indicate the total length median and mean
value respectively. Data: Lightfoot (2017).
Table 2. Descriptive statistics (mean, standard
deviation, and sample size) for total length (mm) of female lizards from
the species CNTE (Cnemidophorus tessalatus) and CNUN (Cnemidophorus
uniparens). Data: Lightfoot (2017).


Species


Mean total lenght (mm)


Standard deviation (mm)


Sample Size


CNTE


244.9


47.3


28


CNUN


147.6


34.6


40


Distributions of total length (plots not included) for female lizards
of the species CNTE (Cnemidophorus tessalatus) and CNUN (Cnemidophorus
uniparens) were relatively normal and symmetric (bell-shaped histogram
and quantile-quantile plot with an almost linear relationship).



On average, the total length of CNTE (Cnemidophorus tessalatus)
females is greater than that of CNUN (Cnemidophorus uniparens) females
(244.89 \(\pm\) 47.32 and 147.6 \(\pm\) 34.55 mm, respectively; mean \(\pm\) 1 standard deviation). The absolute
difference in means is 97.29 mm (a 49.58% difference). The effect size
is large (Cohen’s d = 2.42) and the difference in means is
significant (Welch two-sample t-test: t(46.43) = 9.28, p =
3.75e-12).
Summary
Exploratory data analysis reveals that, on average, the total length
of female lizards of CNTE (Cnemidophorus tessalatus) is greater than
that of CNUN (Cnemidophorus uniparens). This difference in total length
is significant, and the effect size is large.
Citations
Lightfoot, D. 2017. Lizard pitfall trap data (LTER-II, LTER-III) ver
36. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/ff37b4cace16a9943575f3fd7067064e

title: Association Between Respondents’ Political Affiliation and Environmentalist Self-identification
description: In this analysis, I explored the association between respondents' political affiliation (Conservative or Liberal) and their self-identification as environmentalists using a chi-squared test. The analysis, based on survey data from 1,331 U.S. respondents collected in August 2017, aimed to determine whether there is a significant relationship between political affiliation and environmentalist self-identification. The chi-squared test revealed a significant association, indicating that these two variables are not independent.
contents:
Introduction
This report provides an exploratory analysis of the association
between respondents’ political affiliation (Conservative or Liberal) and
environmentalist self-identification (perception of respondents
regarding whether they consider themselves environmentalists). Data was
collected in August 2017 from an online panel of 1,331 anonymous,
nationwide U.S respondents (Andrews Forest LTER Site and C. Batavia.
2019). The association between respondents’ political affiliation and
environmentalist self-identification was explored by a chi-squared test
(significance level (\(\alpha\)) of
0.05). All analyses are in R version 4.0.2 using RStudio version
1.3.1056.






Table 1. Counts and proportions of Conservative or
Liberal survey respondents who responded “Yes”, “No” and “Unsure” to the
statement “I consider myself an environmentalist.” Data: Andrews Forest
LTER Site and C. Batavia (2019).




Yes

There is a significant association between respondents’ political
affiliation (Conservative or Liberal) and environmentalist
self-identification (perception of respondents regarding whether they
consider themselves environmentalists). In other words, political
affiliation and environmentalist self-identification are non-independent
(\(\chi\)2(2) = 81.24,

Summary
Survey data exploration reveals that there is a significant
association (i.e. non-independence) between respondents’ political

title: Exploratory Analysis of Juvenile Snowshoe Hares in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest
description: In this analysis, I explored the data from a capture-recapture study of juvenile snowshoe hares (Lepus americanus) conducted in the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest between 1999 and 2012. The study aimed to investigate trends in hare population over time, compare the weights of male and female juveniles using two-sample t-tests and Cohen’s d for effect size, and examine the relationship between their weight and hind foot length through simple linear regression analysis.
contents:
1. Introduction
This report provides an exploratory analysis of juvenile snowshoe hare (Lepus americanus) surveyed in a capture-recapture study conducted in the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest from 1999 to 2012 (Kielland et al. 2017).
Specifically, this report presents: an exploration of the total number of juvenile snowshoe hares sampled by year in the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest (1999-2012); a comparison of weights for juvenile male and female snowshoe hares; finally, an analysis of the relationship between juvenile weight and hind foot length.
2. Data and analyses
Snowshoe hare data was collected and made available by Dr. Knut Kielland and colleges at the Bonanza Creek Long Term Ecological Research Station in Alaska. The data contains 3197 observations from capture-recapture studies of snowshoe hares, conducted from 1999 to 2012. Following exploratory data visualization, juvenile male and female snowshoe hares weights were compared by a two-sample t-tests (significance level (\(\alpha\)) of 0.05) and differences between groups were described by Cohen’s d effect size. Finally, the relationship between juvenile snowshoe hare weight and hind foot length was explored by simple linear regression.
All analyses are in R version 4.0.2 using RStudio version 1.3.1056.
3. Exploratory findings
A. Annual juvenile snowshoe hare trap counts



Figure 1. Total number of juvenile snowshoe hare (observed via trap capture) by year.
Table 1. Descriptive statistics (mean, median, minimum and maximum counts) for annual counts of juvenile snowshoe hare trappings. Data: Kielland et al. (2017).


Annual Mean


Annual Median


Maximum Count


Minimum Count


31.5


18.5


126


2





Juvenile snowshoe hare (observed via trap capture) were counted by year. The minimum and maximum counts of juvenile hare trappings were 2 and 126 respectively. The mean annual number of juvenile hares trapped was 31.5 with a median annual number of 18.5 (Table 1, Figure 1). There is an overall decline in the annual counts of juvenile snowshoe hare for the period 1999-2012. However, the number of days and traps in the study were not standardized for each year, limiting the utility of this methodology for accurately estimating the juvenile hare population.
B. Juvenile snowshoe hare weights comparison by sex and site



Figure 2. Weight (g) for juvenile snowshoe hare by sex and site (Bonanza Black Spruce, Bonanza Mature, and Bonanza Riparian). Gold (female), teal (male) and coral (NA) points indicate individual observations for weight (grams) of juvenile snowshoe hare. Box endpoints indicate the 25th and 75th percentile values. The black line and black point within the box indicate the weights median and mean value respectively. Data: Kielland et al. (2017).
C. Juvenile hare mean weights comparison by sex
Distributions of weights (plots not included) for juvenile male and female snowshoe hares were relatively normal and symmetric (bell-shaped histogram and quantile-quantile plot with an almost linear relationship).
Table 2. Descriptive statistics (mean, standard deviation, and sample size) for weights (g) of juvenile snowshoe hare trappings by sex. Data: Kielland et al. (2017).


Sex


Mean Weight (g)


Standard deviation (g)


Sample Size


f


855.4


292.3


197


m


945.9


333.2


163





On average, juvenile snowshoe hare males weight slightly more than female juvenile snowshoe hares (945.86 \(\pm\) 333.22 and 855.39 \(\pm\) 292.25 g, respectively; mean \(\pm\) 1 standard deviation).
The absolute difference in means is 90.47 g (a 10.05% difference).
The effect size is small (Cohen’s d = 0.29) and the difference in means is significant (Welch two-sample t-test: t(325.02) = 2.71, p < 0.001).
D. Relationship between juvenile snowshoe hare weight & hind foot length
The relationship between hind foot length (mm) and weight (g) was explored for juvenile snowshoe hares by simple lineal regression. Additional variables as sex or sites were not included in the analysis.



Figure 3. Relationship between hind foot length (mm) and weight (g) for juvenile snowshoe hares. Points indicate individual juvenile snowshoe hare measurements. Linear model summary: \(\beta\)1 = 9.52 g mm-1, p < 0.001, R2 = 0.3, Pearson’s r = 0.55). An equation of this linear model is also displayed in the plot panel. Data: Kielland et al. (2017).
The relationship between hind foot length (mm) and weight (g) for juvenile snowshoe hares appears relatively linear (Figure 3). Simple linear regression showed that hind foot length is not a strong predictor of juvenile snowshoe hares weight (p < 0.001, R2 = 0.3); i.e., only 29.88% of the variance in weight is predictable from the hind foot length. The average slope is \(\beta\) = 9.52 g mm-1; meaning that, on average, we expect weight to increase by 9.52grams for each one millimeter increase in hind foot length. Hind foot length and weight are moderately, and significantly, positively correlated (Pearson’s r = 0.55, p < 0.001).
Diagnostic plots (not included) reveal normally distributed (with a slight skew to the right) residuals.The heteroscedasticity of residuals shown in these plots is a major concern. Linear regression assumes that all residuals are drawn from a population that has a constant variance of the error (homoscedasticity); heteroscedasticity can decrease the predictive capacity of the linear model by underestimating or overestimating uncertainty.
Summary
Juvenile hares data exploration reveals the following findings:
There is a decrease in the observations of juvenile snowshoe hares (observed via trap capture) from 1999 to 2012. However, as the number of days and traps in each year of the study were not standardized it is difficult to accurately estimate the real variation in the juvenile hare population.
Juvenile snowshoe hare males weight, on average, slightly more than female juvenile snowshoe hares. The difference in means is significant but the effect size is small (Cohen’s d = 0.29).
The linear regression exploration of the relationship between hind foot length and weight for juvenile snowshoe hares revealed that hind foot length is not a strong predictor of weight (p < 0.001, R2 = 0.3). At the same time, the observed heteroscedasticity of residuals weakens the predictive capacity of this model.
Citations
Kielland, K., F.S. Chapin, R.W. Ruess, and Bonanza Creek LTER. 2017.Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present ver 22. Environmental Data Initiative.
https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14
